I.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM  
 
1.   The proposed Power Sector Development Program will intensify the implementation of 
on-going reforms and improve the financial sustainability of the power subsector in Tajikistan. The 
country’s single vertically integrated power utility, Joint Stock Holding Company Barqi Tojik, faces 
issue of unsustainable liabilities, weak regulations and inadequate tariffs, corporate governance 
and inadequate metering infrastructure. The program aims to achieve the outcome of improved 
power sector financial sustainability with five outputs: (i) power subsector governance structure 
strengthened (ii) financial management of power utilities improved (iii) sustainable corporate 
management introduced in the new distribution company (iv) subsector’s reform and operational 
capacity strengthened including women’s increased participation in the power subsector, and 
(v) retail billing and collection system modernized. Of the program’s estimated cost of $145 
million, ADB will fund $105 million. The program is included in the Country Operations Business 
Plan, 2020–2022.1 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
 
2.   The cluster transaction technical assistance was approved in March 2020. Subproject 1 
is  ongoing,  and  the  consultants  to  support  gender  mainstreaming  in  project  design, 
implementation and monitoring have been engaged. This Subproject 4 is the second subproject 
to be implemented from 2020.  
 
B.  Subproject Scope 
 
3.   The subproject will strengthen gender mainstreaming of the proposed program to meet 
effective gender mainstreaming categorization. Specifically, the subproject will address the limited 
employment of women in technical occupations in the power subsector, which is predominantly 
composed of male workers. In 2018, the main office of the Joint Stock Holding Company Barqi 
Tojik had a total of 2,350 engineers of which only 283 (or 12%) were females. As Barqi Tojik is 
unbundled into generation, transmission and distribution companies, the subproject will aim to 
increase the pool of potential women technical workers for the power subsector, by supporting 
female graduating students and female graduates of courses related to science, technology, 
engineering, and mathematics (STEM) to undergo technical trainings and underdo on-the-job 
trainings in the power companies.

Background and Rationale 
 
Tajikistan power subsector is predominantly run by men. In 2018, the main office of the Joint 
Stock Holding Company Barqi Tojik (BT) had a total of 11,074 employees, of which 1309 (12%) 
were women. However, these women employees were mostly in non-technical positions. Of the 
total 2350 engineers of BT, only 283 (or 12%) were females. Most technical staff of the BT 
graduated from the following: (i) Technical University of Dushanbe, (ii) Bokhtar Energy Institute, 
(iii) Polytechnic College, (iv) Construction College of Dushanbe in Bokhtar, and (v) a branch of 
the Moscow Institute of Energetics. The proportion of females enrolling in these institutions are 
small. During the schoolyear of 2018–2019, the energy faculty of the Technical University had 
169 females enrolled out of a total 3982 students (or 4%), while the secondary vocational faculty 
in energy enrolled 151 females out of a total of 1769 students (or 9%). The stereotype that the 
energy sector is a man’s domain, is still prevalent. Having girls enrolled in the energy faculties of 
technical institutes and universities is still a novelty.  
 
The subproject will contribute to increasing the number of female students being trained in energy-
related professions and expand the pool of potential women technical workers for the power 
sector. The subproject will specifically support female graduating students and female graduates 
of courses related to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) to undergo 
technical trainings for specific skills required in the power sector, and undergo on-the-job trainings 
in the power companies.

Implementing partner: 
 
ADB seeks a consulting firm to carry out the subproject. The firm should have a solid capacity to 
carry out a gender diagnostic of the power subsector, develop a marketing campaign to attract 
more female students to train for technical jobs, and carry out technical training courses for these 
students.

gender development; or conversely, a university degree relevant to gender and social 
development, with significant training and experience in STEM and engineering-related
